Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Alternative constructions of authority in establishing institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Building on previous research that examines the interpretation and construction of law in organizational contexts, this project evaluates the hypothesis that relevant law both shapes how actors view authorization of new forms of organization under law, and how law in turn is shaped by encounters with alternative understandings regarding the role of locally significant institutions' understandings emanating from practice, the market, or elsewhere- that inform the bureaucratic authorization process. The project will take the authorization of charter schools, significant social institutions, as the site for analysis of the reciprocal shaping of law and organizations.

Although there exists a well-developed literature on the performance and place of charter schools within market-based education reforms, there have been few empirical studies of how the parties relevant to charter governance encounter, invoke, and use the law in the vital moments of school authorization, renewal, and closure. The project will integrate analysis of the sociolegal dimensions of organizational authorization and revocation under law with mapping of relevant organizations. The study uses a multi-method approach with two phases: 1) quantitative analysis of the current and historical population of relevant organizations to reveal patterns and types of establishment, challenged or denied renewal, closure, and legal appeal, with a focus on the participation and significance of legal professionals, and 2) qualitative case studies of specific authorization actions, including analysis of charter petitions and authorization documents and in-depth interviews of the parties to charter authorization. To the field of education research, this project brings needed sociolegal attention to law within educational organizations, spaces characterized by the retention of public accountability in the face of increasing privatization.

By focusing on the ways actors invoke, make use of, and extend the law in the processes of charter school authorization, this study will have important implications for charter operators, the bodies legally tasked with charter oversight, and for policymakers as they evaluate the place of charter schools within educational reform. The project will also train students in methods in the social sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the past 25 years, charter schools have grown rapidly both in number and in popularity through market reforms to education at federal, state, and local district levels. With this rise has come the practical and scholarly focus on charter school quality, approached primarily through the lens of comparative student performance on standardized tests. While results from these inquiries are mixed, poor or mediocre charter performance poses a clear legitimacy problem for the charter school as an educational reform meriting expansion or additional investment. After all, if charters do no better than traditional public schools, how do advocates justify their continued operation or expansion?

 One answer to quality concerns has been to strengthen oversight conducted by charter authorizers, typically local school districts and county boards of education. Yet there remain significant gaps in our understanding of how these authorizers make their decisions to open, renew, or close charter schools. More specifically, we do not understand how the corpus of legal requirements intersects with the local context of authorization, nor how local control and discretion embedded within oversight shapes the regulatory process.  Since charter authorizers hold significant power to structure the educational options of their communities, their actions have consequences for choice and opportunity. What is the role of law in charter oversight, and what are the consequences of legal logics of oversight for charter populations and participants? This study sought to answer these questions.

Following from these central questions, this study examined the role of law as an primary institutional logic of charter oversight in California, the state with the largest and most diverse population of charter schools in the nation. Using concepts from organizational sociology and the sociology of law, the inquiry focused on the moments of greatest authorizer involvement (initial chartering, renewal and closure) in order to assess the claim that charter oversight is equitable, rigorous, and centered on clear legal requirements. I tracked the participation of different actors and their arguments in the crowded field of charter oversight, analyzing how charter authorizers respond to the arguments of participants, from the local district level to the State Board of Education. The project relied on multiple sources, including demographic data on California’s 332 charter authorizers and nearly 1,200 charter schools; minutes from local, county, and state oversight fora; 31 qualitative interviews and three case studies of specific oversight actions to illustrate the diversity and consequences of law in the construction educational quality. In addition, I drew on written materials relevant to charter operation and oversight, including legal opinions, materials from advocacy organizations, charter petitions and renewal documents, and minutes from local school board meetings, as well as their county and state counterparts.

The first central finding positions charter oversight in the charter organizational and strategic action field, exploring the participants, logics, and boundaries revealed in its practice- a contrast to the orderly portrait of regulation suggested by existing legal provision. The second finding examines the legal logic as it intersects and conflicts with alternative logics within oversight, as well as the effects of legal discretion and local politics in chartering decisions. The third central finding focuses on the increasing legalization (and professionalization) of the oversight process and the consequences for participants and authorizers.

Taken together, the findings of this study challenge the prevalent notion that charter quality is an objective organizational fact, and I present evidence that the decisions made by authorizers reflect conflicting institutional currents now present in public education. I conclude that the current legal framework of charter oversight in California creates an open stage for actors to debate the nuances and sources of school quality, the suitability of market logics in public instutitions, and the legitimacy of the charter form itself. Law proves to be a dynamic tool in the hands of diverse participants, permitting mobilization toward different ends: increasing legitimacy of market reforms and language, shoring up historic arrangements of local control, or even facilitating resistance to charter growth. Following research in the law and society movement, law also emerges as an unequally distributed material resource, with advantages accruing to the “repeat players” of charter oversight while disadvantaging the position of less-resourced schools and communities. This work has implications for theories of how law unfolds in the organizational context of public education, as well as for the practical construction of equitable, efficient charter oversight structures.
